captions.text:
00:04
COMM: Most impalas run for their lives at

the sight of a leopard. But this youngster
seems intent on befriending one.

00:16
COMM: This bizarre footage shows the young

antelope nuzzling the killer cats nose and
mouth as it lazes in the clearing.

00:27
COMM: And even when the leopard starts playing
a little rough it makes no attempts to leave.

00:38
COMM: Game ranger Estiaan Houy filmed the

encounter while out with guests in the Kruger
National Park in South Africa.

00:50
COMM: He says the amiable interaction lasted

for an hour before the leopard strolled into
the bush followed by the impala. It's not

known what happened afterwards but as leopards
like all cats are prone to toying with their

prey it's likely the apparent friendship only
lasted until dinner time.

01:09
COMM: We asked Will Fox, senior project manager

for the INGWE Leopard Research program for
a comment on the behaviour and he told us

as much as it would be nice to think predator
and prey can become buddies the incidents

of vegetarian leopards is non-existent. So
the end result is not likely to have ended

title: Leopard 'Befriends' Impala: Unusual Predator - Prey Interaction Caught On Camera

Maybe the leopard was a mother who was deprived of her cubs in some way or 
felt alone. Strange adoptions do happen. It is seen that the leopard is 
being very careful, deliberately not landing even a single wound on the 
impala. Even after being picked up by the head, and we all know that 
leopard could have crushed its brains in an instant, the impala came out 
unharmed and unshaken. That is no coincidence.﻿

comments.author: Matthew Chavez

comments.text:
Notice the only times the leopard starts to get rough is whenever the 
impala turns its back, makes fast movements, or jumps around. Non-human 
animals are closer to robots than humans, they almost always respond 
predictably to specific stimuli. This is why you shouldn't run from a bear, 
this simply triggers their automatic response to pursue and attack. I don't 
think the leopard's behavior is strange at all. I think the impala's is. If 
all impalas simply stood still, or better yet, charged attacking leopards. 
leopards would almost certainly stop hunting them. Again, the worst thing 
to do when attacked by a predator is to run. The best thing to do is fight 
back.﻿
comments.author: Kilgore Trout

comments.text:
Leopards do not befriend impala, they use them as bait, the leopard will 
hurt the baby making it cry for help to get the parents to come closer.﻿
comments.author: roflcopterkklol

comments.text:
Wonderful video to watch and a rare treat for the fortunate eco- tourist, 
but even amateur nature enthusiasts know this drama will end tragically. 
The mother impala , if alive, would not have allowed her baby to get this 
far. This is like an innocent toddler venturing too close to a serial 
killer. Predator/prey behavior occasionally happens - in India and 
Bangladesh, full bellied tigers have been known to nuzzle villagers.﻿
comments.author: Victor Washington

comments.text:
Friendship my ass! The hind legs of the impala baby, especially the inner 
parts are full of deep bloody wounds and scratches! You can see it when the 
impala looks to the left, or is standing to the left. Then the leopard is 
lunging at the face of the impala and scratching it, while the impala is 
jumping away in distress. The leopard is "playing" with the baby quite some 
time, the impala surely tried to get away, but he "told" him to stay with 
"friendly" bites and scratches in the hind legs. Most likely the impala 
gave up and just tries to be with someone, rather being alone and doomed. 
The leopard is most likely just trying to lure the mother to him...using 
the baby as bait.﻿
comments.author: Bailar sonsa

comments.text:
Leopards use smaller prey, like babies, as bait for larger prey. No 
friendship in this video lol.﻿
comments.author: Cherry Pauper

comments.text:
This is what I think went down, the Leopard took down the baby impala's mom 
not too long after the tiny thing was born and the baby imprinted on the 
Leopard as it could be the first thing it saw. Baby animals do that and 
follow them thinking this is their mother. It had no clue and wobbled up 
and was determined to get mommy to feed it. There was no befriending here 
and the Leopard was trying to get the thing to leave it alone. It all 
explains why the baby wouldn't leave. The leopard was trying to nip the 
little things nose as if to say "Look kid, mom was lunch and now if you 
don't leave me alone you will be dinner." Face facts animals and nature are 
not always cutesy and sweet.﻿

comments.author: Joshua Eli

comments.text:
+Joshua Eli I am religious and believe God is the creator of all things. 
But I'm going to be honest. This wasn't friendly behavior. The leopard was 
keeping it to lure the mother for a bigger dinner. And if the leopard can't 
lure the mother, it will eat the baby. I just watched another video before 
this of a leopard doing the exact same thing. Except that you actually saw 
the leopard hooking a claw on it to keep it from running off. The leopard 
even displayed the baby in front of a few adult Impala, who tried to get 
the baby back, but they were too afraid and ran off. After that, the 
leopard dragged the baby into a tree to eat it. I do believe there are few 
moments where animals truly befriend each other, but this is not one of 
them.
